articles.headline: Bringing You a Signal You’re Already Paying For
articles.snippet: Small devices that act as cell towers are poised for big sales. But they cost extra.
articles.abstract: Small devices that act as cell towers are poised for big sales. But they cost extra.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Faced with withering criticism for its spotty iPhone service, AT&T blames in part a shortage of cellphone towers near homes and businesses. But it has a solution: put a miniature cell tower in your living room.

articles.headline: Less Baggage, Big Savings to Airlines
articles.snippet: After most airlines imposed fees to check luggage, travelers are doing it less, but carrying on more items.
articles.abstract: After most airlines imposed fees to check luggage, travelers are doing it less, but carrying on more items.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airlines in the United States started charging for luggage in 2005 by instituting a fee for passengers with more than one bag to check. Soon, even the first bag wasn’t free. Now, Spirit Airlines says it will charge as much as $30 each way for carry-on bags that are too big to fit under the seat.

articles.headline: Novartis Bias Suit to Begin
articles.snippet: A complaint is seeking more than $200 million in damages from a company that has received accolades from Working Mother magazine.
articles.abstract: A complaint is seeking more than $200 million in damages from a company that has received accolades from Working Mother magazine.
articles.lead_paragraph: A class-action lawsuit alleging that Novartis Pharmaceuticals practiced sex discrimination against female employees is set to go to trial on Wednesday in federal court in New York.

articles.headline: In Medicine, the Power of No
articles.snippet: Americans tend to believe more health care is better care. But to cut costs, we’ve got to learn how to say no.
articles.abstract: Americans tend to believe more health care is better care. But to cut costs, we’ve got to learn how to say no.

articles.headline: Palestinians Try a Less Violent Path to Resistance
articles.snippet: The Palestinian Authority is trying to build a virtual state and body politic through nonviolent resistance.
articles.abstract: The Palestinian Authority is trying to build a virtual state and body politic through nonviolent resistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAMALLAH, West Bank — Senior Palestinian leaders — men who once commanded militias — are joining unarmed protest marches against Israeli policies and are being arrested. Goods produced in Israeli settlements have been burned in public demonstrations. The Palestinian prime minister has entered West Bank areas officially off limits to his authority, to plant trees and declare the land part of a future state.

articles.headline: Greek Bond Yields Soar in Sell-Off
articles.snippet: The surge in interest rates on Greek bonds is expected to make it more difficult for the country to borrow.
articles.abstract: The surge in interest rates on Greek bonds is expected to make it more difficult for the country to borrow.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors fled Greek bonds on Tuesday, pushing up the cost of new borrowing for the debt-stricken nation and calling into question a joint rescue plan by the European Union and the International Monetary Fund.

articles.headline: Ensnared by Error on Growing U.S. Watch List
articles.snippet: Terrorist watch lists are likely to expand as officials recalibrate standards for identifying potential threats.
articles.abstract: Terrorist watch lists are likely to expand as officials recalibrate standards for identifying potential threats.
articles.lead_paragraph: Rahinah Ibrahim, a Stanford University doctoral student, arrived at San Francisco International Airport with her 14-year-old daughter for a 9 a.m. flight home to Malaysia. She asked for a wheelchair, having recently had a hysterectomy.

articles.headline: Taxpayer Could Have Kept the $600, but He Put His Country First
articles.snippet: A flaw in the most recent version of TurboTax, the tax-preparation software, may have caused thousands of retired federal employees to unwittingly underpay the Internal Revenue Service.
articles.abstract: A flaw in the most recent version of TurboTax, the tax-preparation software, may have caused thousands of retired federal employees to unwittingly underpay the Internal Revenue Service.
articles.lead_paragraph: A flaw in the most recent version of TurboTax, the nation’s most popular tax-preparation software, may have caused thousands of retired federal employees to overstate their medical deductions and unwittingly underpay the Internal Revenue Service, according to federal officials.

articles.headline: Upbeat Signs Revive Consumers’ Mood for Spending
articles.snippet: New figures show healthy sales growth last month, with Americans starting to buy clothes, jewelry and even cars.
articles.abstract: New figures show healthy sales growth last month, with Americans starting to buy clothes, jewelry and even cars.
articles.lead_paragraph: American consumers are finally coming out of hiding.

articles.headline: Upheaval in Kyrgyzstan Could Imperil Key U.S. Base
articles.snippet: Protests appear to have overthrown the government, calling into question the fate of a U.S.  air base that supports the war in Afghanistan.
articles.abstract: Protests appear to have overthrown the government, calling into question the fate of a U.S.  air base that supports the war in Afghanistan.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — The president of Kyrgyzstan was forced to flee the capital, Bishkek, on Wednesday after bloody protests erupted across the country over his repressive rule, a backlash that could pose a threat to the American military supply line into nearby Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Fed Reviews Find Errors in Oversight of Citigroup
articles.snippet: As the committee examining the causes of the financial crisis began three days of hearings, a review was released that showed problems going back as far as 2005 in the Federal Reserve’s supervision of Citigroup.
articles.abstract: As the committee examining the causes of the financial crisis began three days of hearings, a review was released that showed problems going back as far as 2005 in the Federal Reserve’s supervision of Citigroup.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Citigroup ran into trouble under the noses of federal regulators. But even after taxpayers rescued the financial giant, regulators failed to monitor the company adequately, according to reviews by the Federal Reserve.
articles.byline: By Sewell Chan and Eric Dash
